body: hm, I don't think this is a good first issue! This requires intimate knowledge of the existing codebase and the scitype taxonomy...

issue.title: Type hints

body: Feel free to change the tag, Aaron has a first version based on the forecasting one

issue.title: Forecasting support for multivariate y and multiple input/output types - working prototype

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is a merge/review ready sketch for how multivariate `y` could be supported for multivariate forecasters, alongside the possibility to pass `np.array` and `pd.Series`. This is based on the design in [STEP no.5](https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/tree/main/steps/05_scitype_based_IO_checks), adapted to the new forecasting base class.

The key ingredient are:

* converters parameterized by from, to, and as - in the `convertIO`module. Besides the obvious conversion functionality, the converters can be given access to a dictionary via reference in the `store` argument, where information for inverting lossy conversions (like from `pd.DataFrame` to `np.array`) can be stored
* a new tag `y_type` which encodes the type of `y` that the private `_fit`, `_predict`, and `_update` assume internally - for now, it's just one type and not a list of compatible types
* some logic in the public "plumbing" area of `fit`, `predict`, `update`, which converts inputs to the public layer to the desired input of the logic layer and back

This is for discussion, and I expect major change before we merge.

It might be especially interesting to discuss the following interaction with typing:
the third argument of the converter, the "as" argument, is a scitype, and designed to have the same name as the respective `typing` composite type. Also see discussion in #965, #973 and #974.

Thinking of the logical continuation of this:

* extend this to the other arguments, e.g., `X`
* the individual argument checks like `check_X` etc should be replaced by checks of the kind `check(what, as : scitype)`, e.g., `check(y, "Series")` should replace the less generic `check_y`.
* extend this to time series classification, to support 3D numpy arrays, awkward arrays, nested data frames

A "visionary" pathway may see this working with type annotations that are scitypes, not `typing` machine types, e.g.,
```python
fit(X : Series, Y : Series)
etc
_fit(X: Series, Y : UnivariateSeries)
```
and checks/conversions being done automatically.

body:
So, @ABostrom, @chrisholder, @jambo6, @TonyBagnall, @aiwalter, @mloning, I wanted to hear your opinion on a suggestion how to deal with descriptive type hints and type checks in one.

What I would propose is that our base class `fit` etc look like as follows (below without conversion etc), in the example of the forecaster base class:

```python

@scitype_decorator
def fit(X: Series, Y: Series):
    
    X = check(X)
    Y = check(Y)

    stuff(X,Y)

    self._fit(X.inner, Y.inner)
```

About the ingredients above:
* `Series` is a custom type, or perhaps better class that denotes `scitype`, not machine type
* what `scitype_decorator` does is wrap `X` and `Y` in the declarative type (ligh-weight wrapper), and does part of what `check_series` does now: it annotates `X`, `Y`, with the machine type. E.g.,: `X = Series(X)`, which moves `X` to `X.inner` and adds an `X.scitype = "Series"` attribute
* `check` inspects `X` for validity, and adds a `X.scitype = "DataFrame"` or similar annotation. So after `check`, we know that `X` is valid, and we can read the scitype and the mtype using `X.scitype` and `X.mtype`.
* the remaining `stuff` has access to these declarative type annotations. It could be compatibility checks, conversions, etc.

To avoid misunderstandings:
* we don't expect the user to wrap `X` and `Y` in `Series` already. They can pass a `pd.DataFrame` or `pd.Series` or whatever they like. The type hint is to be read like the union type roughly. The wrapping happens in the decorator.

This proposal has some advantages:

* type annotation in the base class and the user docstrings will be with the "scientific type"
* the scientific type of any object is inspectable, per declarative annotation
* we have a consistent way, across modules, to track and inspect alias mtypes for the same scitype
* this could be eaily combined with a central "register" location of scitypes, mtypes, and/or a central location for validity checking, and the conversions module as sketched in #980

I like the look of this a lot @fkiraly. 

My only comment is (and Im sure this isn't final anyways) is the naming of the type 'Series' to me that implies a pandas Series. I ran into this issue of not knowing what to call my type describing pandas numpy and the other potential input types for clustering and ended up landing on:

`NumpyOrDF = Union[DataFrame, NumpyArray]`

Which equally isn't a good name :joy: . 

So my only question is why isn't the
```
    X = check(X)
    Y = check(Y)
```
inside the decorator (potentially you're just leaving it in fit for consistency)? Is this something we'd want to enforce as you're already mutating X in the decrator.

> I ran into this issue of not knowing what to call my type describing pandas numpy and the other potential input types for clustering and ended up landing on:

We could call it `TimeSeries`? Or `scitype-series` or `ScitypeSeries`, i.e., preface all the type hints with "scitype".

>why isn't the inside the decorator

For consistency is one reason, but also you may want to feed arguments to it depending on tags, and that's easier to read if it's explicit. In that situation, I thought it's better if the decorator logic does not depend on tags or other attributes of the host class, only arguments of the function it's applied to.

More generally, one should be able to read the code in `fit` without knowing that the decorator "wraps" `X` and `Y`, interpreting it purely as helping the type annotation.

I also like TimeSeries, but would we also need to note the type of TimeSeries data, since it is the Scitype? 

UnivariateTimeSeries, MultivariateTimeSeries, PanelTimeSeries?

@RNKuhns, I'm not sure whether we need the difference univariate vs multivariate, but of course we will a separate type for panel, agreed.

Why do I think we may not need uni vs multivariate: I don't think it's that much of a difference in terms of type; the uni vs multivariate capability would also be handled by tags, and type conversion would happen in `fit`. So I don't see a place where we would pass this information as part of a type.
